reviewText: THE OKLAHOMAN is a gentle and heartwarming oater starring Joel McCrea. McCrea makes acting look simple and always seem to have been born in the saddle. Not too much gunplay, but good character development, and a surprising ending. Recommended.

reviewText: Joel McRae plays Doctor John Brighton whose plans to settle in California are derailed when he loses his wife in childbirth .He resolves to settle down in Oklahama with his young daughter and soon becomes a respected member of the small town where he sets up his practice .He is however at odds with one of the big local ranchers ,Cass Dobie (Brad Dexter) who has discovered that oil can be found on the property of a Native American rancher ,Charlie Smith (Michael Pate ).Dobie  is determined to drive out Charlie but any means available .When Charlie ,acting in defence of his property ,kills Dobie's younger brother Dobie sets out to get him convicted and hung, with a view to acquiring his property that way .Brighton sets out to defend Charlie and is helped by another local rancher Anne Barnes  (Barbara Hale ) and by Charlie's nubile daughter Maria (Gloria Talbott)The acting is solid all round and the movie does not fight shy of exposing the casual racism of small town life ,for while most residents are friendly towards the Indians some still view them as uncivilised and a threat to peace .Add some good location photography in warm ,burnished Tecnicolor and you have a decent little movie .It could have done with stronger direction from Francis D Lyons ,a superb editor but average director ,but it will furnish a pleasing 80 or so minutes diversion for the Western lovers

reviewText: Allied Artists Pictures presents "THE OKLAHOMAN" (1957) (80 min/Color) -- Starring Joel McCrea, Barbara Hale, Brad Dexter, Gloria Talbott, Michael Pate & Anthony CarusoDirected by Francis D. LyonHaving lost his wife in childbirth en route to California, Dr. John Brighton (Joel McCrea) builds a new home for himself and his baby daughter in an Oklahoma backwater town, lodging with kindhearted Mrs. Fitzgerald (Esther Dale). As the town grows up around him, Brighton becomes a well-respected local medico, championing the rights of the area's Indian population when nasty rancher Cass Dobie (Brad Dexter) attempts to buy them out cheap. Unbeknownst to the townspeople, Dobie has discovered oil on the land belonging to Charlie Smith (Michael Pate), whose beautiful daughter, Maria (Gloria Talbott), is working as little Louise Brighton's (Laurie Mitchell) nursemaid. When Charlie is forced to kill Cass' brother, Mel (Douglas Dick), in self-defense, Cass vows revenge. Meanwhile, aided by female rancher Anne Barnes (Barbara Hale), Brighton learns about the discovery of oil.Gloria Talbot, a familiar face in TV westerns, is equally attractive on the big screen. Barbara Hale (Perry Mason TV Series) plays the doctor's love interest. And Brad Dexter (Magnificent Seven Film) is the villain.A very underrated Western for Joel McCrea.BIOS:1. Francis D. reviewText: Although Joel McCrea is always good to watch, this is not a good western. It is a very slow and predictable one. I recommend Wichita, Stranger on Horseback and Stars on my Crown.
summary: One of the weakest of McCrea

reviewText: Joel McCrea could play parts like he did in The Oklahoman in his sleep, but one of the things that made him infinitely likable in this kind of role was that he has a soft-spoken, easy going charm that made audiences warm up to him. He was never too hard or boisterous, but solid, kind-hearted and dependable. The Oklahoman is an example of standard McCrea fare, not outstanding, but certainly not the worst of the genre.In this film, McCrea plays a doctor moving out west with his wife and infant daughter. On the trip, the wife gets sick and dies in Oklahoma territory. McCrea decides to stay in a nearby town, and becomes the town doctor. As his daughter grows up, he needs someone to look after her during the day. A young Indian girl whose father is a friend of McCrea moves into his house to help him take care of his daughter. Soon, rumors and gossip about the doctor and young Indian girl spread all over town. Meanwhile, the town bully (played by The Magnificent Seven's Brad Dexter) and his brother discover that the Indian girl's father's land sits on oil. Afterwards, they plot to throw the girl's father off of his land. McCrea comes to their rescue. Also in the mix is a neighboring rancher in love with McCrea, played by Barbara Hale, famous for playing Della Street on TV's Perry Mason.The film doesn't go anywhere unexpected, but it is not a bad film, either. McCrea and the rest of the cast do their jobs well, and The Oklahoman ends up being a decent, entertaining Western.
